Cross-silo Federated Learning with Record-levelÂ PersonalizedÂ DifferentialÂ Privacy

Junxu Liu Renmin University of ChinaThe Peopleâ€™s Republic of China junxu_liu@ruc.edu.cn ,Â  Jian Lou Zhejiang UniversityThe Peopleâ€™s Republic of China jian.lou@zju.edu.cn ,Â  Li Xiong Emory UniversityThe United States of America lxiong@emory.edu ,Â  Jinfei Liu Zhejiang UniversityThe Peopleâ€™s Republic of China jinfeiliu@zju.edu.cn Â andÂ  Xiaofeng Meng Renmin University of ChinaThe Peopleâ€™s Republic of China xfmeng@ruc.edu.cn
Abstract.

Federated learning enhanced by differential privacy has emerged as a popular approach to better safeguard the privacy of client-side data by protecting clientsâ€™ contributions during the training process. Existing solutions typically assume a uniform privacy budget for all records and provide one-size-fits-all solutions that may not be adequate to meet each recordâ€™s privacy requirement. In this paper, we explore the uncharted territory of cross-silo FL with record-level personalized differential privacy. We devise a novel framework named rPDP-FL, employing a two-stage hybrid sampling scheme with both client-level sampling and non-uniform record-level sampling to accommodate varying privacy requirements. A critical and non-trivial problem is to select the ideal per-record sampling probability qğ‘q given the personalized privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon. We introduce a versatile solution named Simulation-CurveFitting, allowing us to uncover a significant insight into the nonlinear correlation between qğ‘q and Îµğœ€\varepsilon and derive an elegant mathematical model to tackle the problem. Our evaluation demonstrates that our solution can provide significant performance gains over the baselines that do not consider personalized privacy preservation.

Personalized privacy, RÃ©nyi differential privacy, Federated learning

1. Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) (mcmahan2017communication, ; kairouz2019advances, ) is a recent machine learning (ML) framework that was motivated by data privacy. In comparison to centralized ML, it eliminates the need for centralized data sharing and has the potential to harness decentralized data for powerful predictive models while alleviating individual privacy concerns. The distinctive feature is its decentralized architecture, where multiple institutions (e.g., hospitals or banks) or devices (e.g., smartphones, IoT devices (DBLP:conf/mobisys/ChenWZQHWFP23, ; DBLP:journals/pvldb/GaoCLXPLDZ23, )) collaborate in training a joint model under the coordination of a central server while keeping the data local. This paper primarily focuses on the former case, also known as cross-silo FL (DBLP:conf/nips/LiuHWS22, ), where each client (institution) holds a local dataset comprising personal data records. For simplicity, we assume each record is associated with a single user (e.g. patient or customer) who does not contribute the same record to multiple clients simultaneously.

Although data are not directly shared in FL, potential adversaries (e.g., the honest-but-curious server or untrusted clients) might engage in indirect privacy violations via reconstruction or inference attacks (hitaj2017deep, ; rigaki2023survey, ; tolpegin2020data, ; wang2019beyond, ; zhu2019deep, ). Differential privacy (DP), known as the de facto standard for private data analysis, has been introduced to FL algorithm design (DBLP:conf/aistats/LowyGR23, ; DBLP:conf/iclr/LowyR23, ; DBLP:conf/aaai/LiuZ0LC23; DBLP:journals/pacmmod/Xiang0L023, ; DBLP:journals/pvldb/LiWL23, ; DBLP:conf/ccs/MaddockC0MJ22, ; DBLP:conf/sensys/GaoTWC22, ). This integration ensures rigorous privacy protection for participants (clients or records) by introducing controlled perturbation into the computation of the intermediate model parameters transferred between clients and the server (mcmahan2017learning, ). While standard DP provides the means to quantify the extent of privacy protection through a positive real-valued parameter Îµğœ€\varepsilon (aka privacy budget), it imposes identical privacy safeguards on every participant involved. This uniformity cannot reflect the reality of diverse privacy expectations among people and can lead to significant utility costs (jorgensen2015conservative, ; ebadi2015differential, ; boenisch2023have, ). It is desirable to allow each participant to set their expected privacy budget reflecting their personal privacy preferences.

With this objective in mind, personalized differential privacy (PDP) (jorgensen2015conservative, ; ebadi2015differential, ) was introduced and has been investigated in various scenarios including statistical analysis (jorgensen2015conservative, ; ebadi2015differential, ; chen2016private, ) and centralized machine learning (ML) (feldman2021individual, ; boenisch2023have, ), and federated learning (liu2021projected, ). For FL, Liu et al. (liu2021projected, ) proposed the concept of heterogeneous DP in FL, where records within a single client share the same privacy budget, but different clients may have varying privacy budgets. We refer to this specific setting as client-level PDP-FL for clarity. In contrast, this paper introduces a broader setting where even records within the same client may have distinctive privacy preferences, referred to as record-level PDP-FL (rPDP-FL in short). Figure 1 provides an illustrative example of the latter case in a healthcare context. To the best of our knowledge, record-level PDP-FL has not yet been investigated.

From a technical standpoint, the essence of implementing record-level PDP lies in ensuring each recordâ€™s accumulative privacy cost aligns with its predetermined privacy budget during the entire training process. This emphasizes the need for an effective privacy budget allocation strategy. When it comes to achieving PDP in a centralized ML setting (centralized PDP), some studies (rogers2016privacy, ; feldman2021individual, ) use even privacy budgets across all records during every iteration of training, and records with smaller privacy budgets will be filtered out of the training process once their privacy budgets run out. This approach may trigger catastrophic forgetting (kirkpatrick2017overcoming, ; goodfellow2013empirical, ), a situation where the learned model could potentially â€œforgetâ€ the knowledge from records that terminate early, eventually leading to degraded model performance. A more promising strategy involves achieving simultaneous depletion of privacy budgets for all records by developing DP mechanisms coupled with non-uniform sampling (jorgensen2015conservative, ; boenisch2023have, ). The fundamental theory underlying it is the â€œprivacy amplification by random samplingâ€ theorem (li2012sampling, ; abadi2016deep, ; balle2018privacy, ; wang2019subsampled, ; zhu2019poission, ) which implies individuals with lower inclusion (sampling) probabilities qğ‘q will incur less privacy cost (leading to smaller privacy budget). Boenisch et al. (boenisch2023have, ) introduced a binary search-based approach to determine an approximate optimal qâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘01q\in[0,1] for each record with a specific privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon. The computation of the accumulative privacy cost for each record is based on Mironov et al. (mironov2019renyi, ) in which RÃ©nyi Differential Privacy (RDP) (mironov2017renyi, ; mironov2019renyi, ) is employed for tight privacy accounting. However, their approach is impractical when all recordsâ€™ privacy budgets are distributed continuously and can cover a spectrum of values, due to the scalability and computational costs associated with the per-record search process.

Overall, there exist significant research gaps in achieving record-level PDP-FL. First, the existing theoretical findings on RDP-based privacy accounting (mironov2019renyi, ; zhu2019poission, ) are no longer adequate for the needs of analyzing each recordâ€™s accumulative privacy cost in FL applications. Intuitively, the two-stage sampling process, i.e., client-level and record-level sampling, will further increase uncertainty for potential adversaries to infer whether a â€œtargetâ€ record is a member of a client and hence further amplify the privacy protection. Second, the existing binary search-based approach (boenisch2023have, ) for finding the optimal sampling probability qğ‘q in centralized PDP is not efficient. A desirable way is to directly compute a sampling probability given a privacy budget for each record. However, itâ€™s non-trivial to derive an explicit closed-form solution due to the highly nonlinear and less interpretable RDP-based privacy accounting.

Contributions. Our key contributions are outlined as follows.

  1. (1)

    We formalize a real-world problem in federated learning concerning record-level personalized differential privacy. To solve this problem, we propose a novel framework called rPDP-FL. The essence of this framework is a two-stage hybrid sampling scheme which comprises a uniform client-level sampling process and a non-uniform record-level sampling process. Specifically, the per-client sampling probability is assumed as a hyperparameter and publicly known by both the server and all clients, while the per-record sampling probability is proportional to each recordâ€™s privacy budget and determined by the client to which it belongs.

  2. (2)

    We formally analyze the enhanced privacy amplification effect of the two-stage hybrid sampling scheme. This RDP-based theoretical investigation fills a gap in existing research and facilitates a more favorable trade-off between privacy and utility.

  3. (3)

    We devise an efficient and general strategy named Simulation-CurveFitting (SCF) to identify the sampling probabilities for all records given their personalized privacy budgets. Our simulations with varying sampling probabilities enables the identification of an elegant mathematical function discerning the relationship between per-record sampling probabilities and their accumulative privacy cost. An important insight arises: the tight upper bound on the accumulative privacy cost of rPDP-FL can be modeled by a simple exponential function w.r.t. its record-level sampling probability.

  4. (4)

    We simulate three potential personalized privacy scenarios and conduct a comprehensive evaluation on two real-world datasets. We first show that our SCF strategy outperforms the existing PDP methods for centralized ML (boenisch2023have, ; feldman2021individual, ) in model utility and computational efficiency. Additionally, we demonstrate that rPDP-FL significantly enhances the utility of the joint model compared to baseline methods that do not incorporate personalized privacy preservation.

2. Related Work

Personalized Personalized Privacy. The concept of personalized DP (PDP) was initially introduced by Ebadi et al (ebadi2015differential, ) and Jorgensen et al. (jorgensen2015conservative, ), focusing on basic private statistical analysis tasks with the standard Îµğœ€\varepsilon-DP framework. Notably, the Sample mechanism proposed in (jorgensen2015conservative, ) demonstrated the feasibility of implementing PDP by combining DP mechanisms (e.g., Laplace or Gaussian mechanism) with non-uniform record-level sampling.

Recent work studied PDP in centralized ML (boenisch2023have, ) built on top of the non-uniform sampling strategy and proposed a binary search-based approach to find a suitable sampling probability qğ‘q as a decimal value within the range of 0 to 1 for each record given a target privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon. It is, however, computationally demanding for the more realistic settings in this paper where recordsâ€™ privacy budgets are distributed continuously (e.g., follow a Gaussian or Pareto distribution) and can cover a range of values. Another line of work (rogers2016privacy, ; feldman2021individual, ) considers all recordsâ€™ privacy budgets to be uniform during each iteration of the training process. Two individual privacy accounting techniques named privacy odometer and privacy filter are designed to monitor and restrict accumulative privacy costs for individual records throughout the training process so that a record will be excluded from the subsequent training iterations once its privacy budget is exhausted. This poses a potential risk catastrophic forgetting (kirkpatrick2017overcoming, ; goodfellow2013empirical, ) and may lead to downgraded model performance.

Federated Learning with DP and Personalized DP. We discuss existing work on federated learning with DP in two aspects: (1) the granularity of the DP guarantee, i.e., what information is protected (each client, or each record), and (2) the level of personalization for DP, i.e., who has the right to specify the privacy budget (the central server, each client, or each record).

  • â€¢

    Client- vs. record-level privacy protection. There is rich literature exploring DP-FL framework concerning potential adversaries. More specifically, these adversaries may be either solely recipients of the global model parameters (i.e., the other untrusted clients or third parties) or recipients of local model updates (i.e. the honest-but-curious central server). This distinction leads to two types of DP guarantees: client-level DP and record-level DP. The former is achieved by adding random Gaussian noise to the aggregated local model updates to hide a single clientâ€™s contribution (geyer2017differentially, ), while the latter requires each client to perturb its computed gradients locally to obscure each recordâ€™s contribution (mcmahan2017learning, ; wei2020federated, ; NEURIPS2022_2788b4cd, ; DBLP:conf/iclr/LowyR23, ). Our primary focus lies on achieving record-level protection.

  • â€¢

    Client- vs. record-level privacy personalization. As mentioned earlier, the majority of approaches offer uniform privacy guarantees for all records involved, based on the one-sided considerations of the central server. Only a few studies recognize the necessity of privacy personalization within FL applications. Liu et al. (liu2021projected, ) introduced the concept of heterogeneous DP and developed a projection-based framework to accommodate diverse privacy budgets among different clients. Although the work (NEURIPS2022_2788b4cd, ) also proposed a similar notion known as silo-specific sample-level DP, it primarily focused on addressing data heterogeneity challenges and did not address varying privacy needs. Liu et al. (liu2023echo, ), on the other hand, centered on cross-device FL and achieved personalized local differential privacy (PLDP) for clientsâ€™ local model gradients. However, it requires a large number of clients for reasonable utility. Our research represents the first attempt to explore record-level privacy personalization in cross-silo FL.

3. Preliminaries

Differential Privacy (DP) is a robust and mathematically rigorous definition of privacy. It allows for the quantification of the information leaked by an algorithm about its input data. While the standard (Îµ,Î´ğœ€ğ›¿\varepsilon,\delta)-DP is widely used in a broad range of literature, it may not be suitable for some settings. The following are two notable limitations associated with (Îµ,Î´ğœ€ğ›¿\varepsilon,\delta)-DP recognized in literature:

  1. (1)

    (Îµ,Î´ğœ€ğ›¿\varepsilon,\delta)-DP provides uniform privacy guarantees for the entire dataset regardless of the individualsâ€™ preferences;

  2. (2)

    (Îµ,Î´ğœ€ğ›¿\varepsilon,\delta)-DP offers a relatively loose composition bound and thus it is not suitable to track and analyze the overall privacy cost of complex iterative algorithms which will lead to poor privacy and utility tradeoff.

In this study, our aim is to design a finely-tailored algorithm with personalized privacy that effectively tackles the aforementioned challenges in the context of federated learning applications. We first review the notions of personalized differential privacy (PDP) and RÃ©nyi differential privacy (RDP), both of which form building blocks for our privacy analysis and algorithm design. More specifically, PDP tailors the level of privacy protection based on the specific privacy preferences of each record. RDP offers a versatile framework for tight privacy accounting and better privacy-utility trade-offs.

3.1. Personalized Differential Privacy

Personalized DP is a variation of DP that bounds the individual privacy cost for each record in the dataset. Remark 1.

Although Î´ğ›¿\delta is also an important DP parameter and technically its value could be randomly specified like Îµğœ€\varepsilon, we assume all records share a common Î´ğ›¿\delta with a small, positive default value in this paper based on the following two considerations.

  • â€¢

    On the one hand, Î´ğ›¿\delta is commonly taken to be â€œsub-polynomially smallâ€, that is, a rule-of-thumb is that it should be much smaller than the inverse of any polynomial in the size of the datasetÂ (dwork2014algorithmic, ; dwork2016concentrated, ). Since individuals may not have access to the complete dataset or information about its size, it becomes difficult for them to properly set a value for Î´ğ›¿\delta that meets the desired privacy budgets.

  • â€¢

    On the other hand, the choices of Îµğœ€\varepsilon and the choices of Î´ğ›¿\delta are statistically independent, that is, for two different records d1,d2âˆˆDsubscriptğ‘‘1subscriptğ‘‘2ğ·d_{1},d_{2}\in D, if Îµ1â‰¥Îµ2subscriptğœ€1subscriptğœ€2\varepsilon_{1}\geq\varepsilon_{2}, it is not necessarily always Î´1â‰¥Î´2subscriptğ›¿1subscriptğ›¿2\delta_{1}\geq\delta_{2} (and vice versa). We argue this issue is complicated and leave it as an open problem.

The Sample Mechanism. Building upon the findings of privacy amplification by random samplingÂ (li2012sampling, ; abadi2016deep, ; balle2018privacy, ; wang2019subsampled, ; zhu2019poission, ), Jorgensen et al. (jorgensen2015conservative, ) propose the Sample mechanism. It achieves (â„°,0â„°0\mathcal{E},0)-PDP by applying an arbitrary mechanism that satisfies Îµğœ€\varepsilon-DP on a subset of data records which is obtained by a non-uniform Poisson sampling procedure. Our work is inspired by this idea but encounters greater challenges due to the utilization of RDP, detailed in Section 4.2.

3.2. RÃ©nyi Differential Privacy

RÃ©nyi differential privacy (RDP) utilizes the asymmetric measure of RÃ©nyi divergence to quantify the privacy guarantee. Note that with a controlling parameter Î±â‰ 1ğ›¼1\alpha\neq 1, the RÃ©nyi divergence of order Î±ğ›¼\alpha from distribution Qğ‘„Q to Pğ‘ƒP is:

DÎ±â€‹(Pâˆ¥Q)â‰œ1Î±âˆ’1â€‹logâ¡ğ”¼oâˆ¼Qâ€‹[(Pâ€‹(o)Qâ€‹(o))Î±].â‰œsubscriptğ·ğ›¼conditionalğ‘ƒğ‘„1ğ›¼1subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ‘œğ‘„delimited-[]superscriptğ‘ƒğ‘œğ‘„ğ‘œğ›¼\begin{split}D_{\alpha}(P\|Q)\triangleq\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\mathbb{E}_{o\sim Q}\left[\left(\frac{P(o)}{Q(o)}\right)^{\alpha}\right].\end{split}

Let P=ğ’œâ€‹(D)ğ‘ƒğ’œğ·P=\mathcal{A}(D) and Q=ğ’œâ€‹(Dâ€²)ğ‘„ğ’œsuperscriptğ·â€²Q=\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime}), then (Î±,Ïğ›¼ğœŒ\alpha,\rho)-RDP is achieved by simultaneously bounding the RÃ©nyi divergence of two directions, denoted by DÎ±â†”â€‹(Pâˆ¥Q)â‰œmaxâ¡{DÎ±â€‹(Pâˆ¥Q),DÎ±â€‹(Qâˆ¥P)}â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğ·ğ›¼â†”conditionalğ‘ƒğ‘„subscriptğ·ğ›¼conditionalğ‘ƒğ‘„subscriptğ·ğ›¼conditionalğ‘„ğ‘ƒD_{\alpha}^{\leftrightarrow}(P\|Q)\triangleq\max\{D_{\alpha}(P\|Q),D_{\alpha}(Q\|P)\}.

Definition 0 ((Î±,Ïğ›¼ğœŒ\alpha,\rho)-RÃ©nyi Differential Privacy (mironov2017renyi, )).

A randomized mechanism ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} satisfies (Î±,Ïğ›¼ğœŒ\alpha,\rho)-RDP with order Î±âˆˆ(1,âˆ)ğ›¼1\alpha\in(1,\infty) if for any pair of adjacent datasets D,Dâ€²âˆˆğ”»ğ·superscriptğ·â€²ğ”»D,D^{\prime}\in\mathbb{D}, it holds that

(1) DÎ±â†”â€‹(ğ’œâ€‹(D)âˆ¥ğ’œâ€‹(Dâ€²))â‰¤Ï.superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ›¼â†”conditionalğ’œğ·ğ’œsuperscriptğ·â€²ğœŒ\begin{split}D_{\alpha}^{\leftrightarrow}(\mathcal{A}(D)\|\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime}))\leq\rho.\end{split}

Different from the traditional (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP, which measures privacy leakage by utilizing the max divergence of two output distributions, RDP allows for a continuous spectrum of privacy measures. More specifically, as Î±â†’âˆâ†’ğ›¼\alpha\rightarrow\infty, Dâˆâ€‹(ğ’œâ€‹(D)âˆ¥ğ’œâ€‹(Dâ€²))subscriptğ·conditionalğ’œğ·ğ’œsuperscriptğ·â€²D_{\infty}(\mathcal{A}(D)\|\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime})) is equal to the max divergence (dwork2014algorithmic, ); and limÎ±â†’1DÎ±â€‹(ğ’œâ€‹(D)âˆ¥ğ’œâ€‹(Dâ€²))subscriptâ†’ğ›¼1subscriptğ·ğ›¼conditionalğ’œğ·ğ’œsuperscriptğ·â€²\lim_{\alpha\rightarrow 1}D_{\alpha}(\mathcal{A}(D)\|\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime})) can be verified to be equal to the expected value of the privacy cost random variable câ€‹(o;ğ’œ,D,Dâ€²)â‰œlnâ¡Prâ¡[ğ’œâ€‹(D)âˆˆo]Prâ¡[ğ’œâ€‹(Dâ€²)âˆˆo]â‰œğ‘ğ‘œğ’œğ·superscriptğ·â€²Prğ’œğ·ğ‘œPrğ’œsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘œc(o;\mathcal{A},D,D^{\prime})\triangleq\ln\frac{\Pr[\mathcal{A}(D)\in o]}{\Pr[\mathcal{A}(D^{\prime})\in o]} (mironov2017renyi, ). This characteristic enables RDP to provide a sharper privacy quantification and become one of the most popular privacy analysis tools, especially adept at handling composite mechanisms like differentially private stochastic gradient descent (DP-SGD) (abadi2016deep, ).

We provide the following useful lemmas which are important primitives for the design of our FL algorithm and privacy analysis.

Lemma 0 (Transition from RDP to DP (mironov2017renyi, )).

If ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} is an (Î±,Ïğ›¼ğœŒ\alpha,\rho)-RDP mechanism, it also satisfies (Ï+logâ¡1/Î´Î±âˆ’1,Î´ğœŒ1ğ›¿ğ›¼1ğ›¿\rho+\frac{\log{1/\delta}}{\alpha-1},\delta)-DP for any 0<Î´<10ğ›¿10<\delta<1.

Lemma 0 (Adaptive sequential composition (mironov2017renyi, )).

Privacy Bounds Visualization. The privacy guarantee under RDP can be depicted as a curve of RÃ©nyi divergence, aka., the RDP budget curve, over the continuous range of Î±ğ›¼\alpha values (mironov2017renyi, ). For a clear understanding, we visualize the RDP budget curve of the PoiSG mechanism with uniform sampling probability qğ‘q in Figure 2 (left). When q=1ğ‘1q=1, the PoiSG mechanism is reduced to a standard Gaussian mechanism whose RDP budget curve is a straight line (mironov2017renyi, ). For the RDP budget curves with q<1ğ‘1q<1, there exists a phase transition that happens around Î±â€‹qâ€‹eÏâ€‹(Î±)â‰ˆqâˆ’1ğ›¼ğ‘superscriptğ‘’ğœŒğ›¼superscriptğ‘1\alpha qe^{\rho(\alpha)}\approx q^{-1} (zhu2019poission, ). As qğ‘q gets larger, this transition tends to appear earlier and get more indistinct.

Based on Lemma 6, we can obtain the corresponding DP budget curve given a desired Î´ğ›¿\delta and then find the smallest Îµğœ€\varepsilon by solving the optimization problem below (abadi2016deep, ):

(3) Îµâˆ—â‰œminÎ±â¡{Ï+logâ¡(1/Î´)Î±âˆ’1}.â‰œsuperscriptğœ€subscriptğ›¼ğœŒ1ğ›¿ğ›¼1\displaystyle\varepsilon^{*}\triangleq\min_{\alpha}\left\{\rho+\frac{\log(1/\delta)}{\alpha-1}\right\}.

Corollary 38 in (wang2019subsampled, ) proves the unimodality/quasi-convexity of this optimization problem. Figure 2 (right) demonstrates the existence of an optimal order Î±âˆ—superscriptğ›¼\alpha^{*}, corresponding to the minimum Îµâˆ—superscriptğœ€\varepsilon^{*}.

Remark 2.

Instead of exploring an infinite range of real numbers Î±âˆˆ(1,âˆ)ğ›¼1\alpha\in(1,\infty), practitioners often opt to predefine a finite collection of RDP orders to effectively capture the minimum Îµâˆ—superscriptğœ€\varepsilon^{*}. This trick has been implemented in leading DP libraries such as Opacus (opacus, ), Tensorflow Privacy333https://github.com/tensorflow/privacy, etc.

4. Federated Learning with Record-level Personalized DP

We target the typical supervised FL task with a central server and a set of clients ğ’={C1,â€¦,CM}ğ’subscriptğ¶1â€¦subscriptğ¶ğ‘€\mathcal{C}=\{C_{1},\dots,C_{M}\}. Our goal is to learn a globally shared model with parameters ğ±âˆˆâ„dğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} by solving the following empirical risk problem

with the privacy guarantee of record-level personalized differential privacy (as stated in Def. 1 below).

Definition 0 (Federated Learning with Record-level Personalized Differential Privacy).

Given Î´â‰¥0ğ›¿0\delta\geq 0. Let ğ’Ÿ=â‹ƒi=1MDiğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ·ğ‘–\mathcal{D}=\bigcup_{i=1}^{M}D_{i} and â„°=â‹ƒi=1M{Îµi,j}jâˆˆ[Ni]â„°superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘—delimited-[]subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\mathcal{E}=\bigcup_{i=1}^{M}\{\varepsilon_{i,j}\}_{j\in[N_{i}]}. FedAvg and Two-stage Sampling Scheme. The most fundamental approach for solving the non-private optimization problem in Eq. (4) is federated average (FedAvg) (mcmahan2017communication, ). Despite numerous improved methods being proposed to tackle FedAvgâ€™s limitations like data heterogeneity or communication efficiency (karimireddy2020scaffold, ; li2020federated, ; hanzely2020lower, ; li2021ditto, ), most of them still adhere to a two-stage sampling scheme (i.e., outer client sampling followed by the inner record sampling) together with SGD-based learning paradigm, as illustrated in Figure 3. Given the primary aim of this work is the establishment of a record-level personalized privacy protection mechanism, we choose FedAvg as the backbone of our FL framework and adopt DP-SGD (abadi2016deep, ) during each clientâ€™s local training process to achieve record-level protection. We expect our proposed rPDP-FL to be extendable to work with other two-stage sampling FL methods listed above.

4.1. Solution Overview

We employ a two-stage hybrid sampling scheme within the FedAvg algorithm to obtain a global model using clientsâ€™ local datasets while ensuring diverse individual privacy preferences. This innovative framework for private FL, termed rPDP-FL, differs from the classic approach in three key aspects:

  • â€¢

    Initialization: Each client allocates a customized sampling probability qi,jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—q_{i,j} to every record in its local dataset, tailored to the recordâ€™s specific privacy budget.

  • â€¢

    Stage 1: Client-level Poisson sampling (uniform): at the beginning of round tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T], the central server selects a random subset of clients ğ’Ë‡tsuperscriptË‡ğ’ğ‘¡\check{\mathcal{C}}^{t} via Poisson sampling with uniform per-client sampling probability Î»âˆˆ[0,1]ğœ†01\lambda\in[0,1] and dispatches the up-to-date global model ğ±tsuperscriptğ±ğ‘¡\mathbf{x}^{t} to these selected clients.

  • â€¢

    Stage 2: Record-level Poisson sampling (non-uniform): each client selected in the above stage performs a certain number of DP-SGD iterations locally and independently and uploads the model updates to the central server. During each iteration, the mini-batches are drawn from the whole local dataset via Poisson sampling with non-uniform per-record sampling probabilities.

Itâ€™s worth highlighting that rPDP-FL solely alters the sampling processes (except for the initialization step) and remains detached from the intricacies associated with the learning process. This feature enables its broader applicability to any non-private FL frameworks that incorporate a two-stage sampling process. The pseudocode is presented in Algorithm 1 and the complete version will be shown in Algorithm 3.

4.2. Challenges

To offer reasonable personalized privacy guarantees in practical applications while maximizing the utility of the global model, the development of Algorithm 1 faces a dual challenge in both theory and practice.

The privacy analysis challenge. It is essential to explore privacy analysis methods (rather than solely relying on the traditional privacy notion of (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP and its related properties) to establish as â€tightâ€ as possible the theoretical upper bounds for the accumulative privacy cost of each individual to enhance privacy and utility tradeoff.

The parameter estimation challenge. For practical purposes, an efficient and effective parameter estimation strategy must be adopted to select appropriate hyperparameters for the privacy algorithm (specifically, to determine suitable sampling probabilities for all records). This ensures that the estimated accumulative privacy cost for each individual closely reaches the level of their chosen privacy budget.

To tackle these challenges, we first establish theoretical upper bounds for the accumulative privacy cost given the sampling probabilities, as elaborated in Section 5. Then, we propose an efficient and general strategy named Simulation-CurveFitting (SCF) in Section 6. As illustrated in Figure 4, SCF aims to explore the mathematical relation between privacy cost and their sampling probabilities, so that the sampling probabilities can be derived given the pre-determined personalized privacy budgets.

5. Privacy Analysis

5.1. Privacy Objectives and Key Results

We will analyze the upper bound of the accumulative privacy cost for any single record in Algorithm 1, which can be broken down into the following three basic nested routines:

  1. (1)

    Local multi-step update at the client, which can be abstracted as an adaptive combination of Ï„ğœ\tau PoiSG mechanisms.

  2. (2)

    Global parameter aggregation at the server, which can be viewed as a complex mechanism integrating equally sampled Poisson processes, local iterations, and data-independent post-processing of the results of the local iterations of the sampled clients.

  3. (3)

    Global multi-round update, which can be perceived as an adaptive combination of Tğ‘‡T parameter aggregation mechanisms above.

Key Results. The key results are presented below in Theorem 3 and Lemma 2. The detailed proof and analysis are in next subsection.

Lemma 0.

Suppose that ğ’Ë‡tsuperscriptË‡ğ’ğ‘¡\check{\mathcal{C}}^{t} is a subset of clients selected at round tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]. Proof.

5.2.1. Local Multi-step Update

According to Fact 1 which aligns with the decentralized nature of FL, the privacy analysis of the local multi-step update process essentially follows the existing theoretical results based on the typical DP-SGD algorithm. The only difference is that now we need to characterize the privacy cost for each record since the sampling probabilities of the records are different from each other.

5.2.3. Global Multi-round Update

Putting all the pieces together, the proof of Theorem 3 can be further derived by leveraging the adaptive composition theorem of RDP as shown in Lemma 7.

6. Selecting Sampling Probability

In this section, we explore how to select a sampling probability qğ‘q for every single record to achieve an estimated privacy cost that closely aligns with the desired privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon, on the condition that the other factors (e.g., T,Ï„ğ‘‡ğœT,\tau, Ïƒğœ\sigma and Î´ğ›¿\delta) remain constant.

6.1. Simulation-CurveFitting

Given the theoretical result in Theorem 3, it would be ideal if we could directly derive a sampling probability for each record given its predetermined personalized privacy budget. Yet, it is non-trivial to derive an explicit closed-form expression due to the complexity arising from the optimization process and the highly nonlinear nature of the tight bound ÏFâ€‹LsubscriptğœŒğ¹ğ¿\rho_{FL}. Existing methods resort to numerical methods to handle this absence of closed-form issue and approximately obtain the sampling probability, e.g., by quick search methods (boenisch2023have, ). However, these numerical methods become computationally demanding when applied to our case. Here, we introduce a new and effective strategy termed Simulation-CurveFitting (SCF). As the name suggests, this approach consists of the following two stages, and the specific steps are outlined in Algorithm 2.

Stage I: Simulation. We aim to elucidate the relationship between qğ‘q and Îµğœ€\varepsilon through a series of simulation experiments. In the beginning, we establish two finite sets of candidate values: the first consists of various sampling probabilities, which we refer to as Î Î \Pi; the second consists of a sequence of discrete RDP orders denoted as ğ”¸ğ”¸\mathbb{A}. For each qâˆˆÎ ğ‘Î q\in\Pi, we compute the DP budget curves and then find the corresponding lowest value Îµâˆ—superscriptğœ€\varepsilon^{*}. For illustration, we show a series of DP budget curves for the rPDP-FL algorithm in Figure 5 (left), corresponding to varying values of qğ‘q555Some of the other parameters used include: T=20, Ï„ğœ\tau=5, Î»ğœ†\lambda=0.5, Ïƒğœ\sigma=1.0, and Î´ğ›¿\delta=1e-3.. The minimum value on each curve is then used to plot the optimum DP budget w.r.t. the corresponding sampling probability on the right figure. The pseudocode is illustrated in lines 3-6 of Algorithm 2.

Stage II: CurveFitting. In Figure 5 (right), we depict the one-to-one correspondence between the optimum DP budgets and their respective sampling probabilities (represented as a series of dots) across various parameter settings (represented by different colors). This visualization reveals a compelling observation â€“ a mathematical function may potentially model the tight upper bound on the accumulative privacy cost w.r.t. its sampling probability. Armed with this insight, we employ curve-fitting tools (2020SciPy-NMeth, ) to approximate the correlation between qğ‘q and Îµğœ€\varepsilon. Our chosen best-fit is a simple exponential function in the form

Îµ^âˆ—â‰ˆfâ€‹(q)â‰œeaâ‹…q+b+c,superscript^ğœ€ğ‘“ğ‘â‰œsuperscriptğ‘’â‹…ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘\hat{\varepsilon}^{*}\approx f(q)\triangleq e^{a\cdot q+b}+c,

as stated in Line 7 of Algorithm 2. Our best-fit function is more concise and elegant than the one given in Eq.(8), allowing inverse computation of the sampling probability qğ‘q given the privacy cost. We refer to the inverse function as sampling probability estimator, denoted as Fâ€‹(Îµ)ğ¹ğœ€F(\varepsilon), which takes a privacy budget Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 as input and outputs a valid sampling probability qâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘01q\in[0,1]. In particular, if an input Îµğœ€\varepsilon exceeds the optimum DP budget corresponding to qğ‘q=1.0, denoted as Îµâˆ—â€‹(1.0)superscriptğœ€1.0\varepsilon^{*}(1.0), the output probability qğ‘q is projected to 1.0. See Line 8 of Algorithm 2 for more details.

Measures for goodness-of-fit. We utilize the R2superscriptğ‘…2R^{2} value (also known as the coefficient of determination) to quantify how well the estimated privacy cost by the curve fitting function matches the privacy cost derived from the privacy accounting, ranging from 0 (no correlation) to 1 (perfect positive correlation). As per the empirical results illustrated in Figure 5 (right), the best-fit model exhibits an R2superscriptğ‘…2R^{2} value exceeding 99%. This demonstrates strong evidence of the modelâ€™s ability to derive the sampling probability for each record based on their desired privacy budget.

6.2. Complete Algorithm of rPDP-FL

The SCF strategy has been further integrated into Algorithm 1, with some tweaks and improvements in the initialization and sampling procedures. A comprehensive outline of rPDP-FL is provided in Algorithm 3.

The per-record sampling probability initialization. At the onset of the learning process, the server will compute the sampling probability estimator Fğ¹F and distribute it to all clients. Note that this computation does not rely on personal data from sensitive records stored locally, hence no risk of compromising the privacy of these records. On the client side, the per-record sampling probabilities will be calculated by directly plugging in their privacy budgets Îµi,jsubscriptğœ€ğ‘–ğ‘—\varepsilon_{i,j} into the received sampling probability estimator. All clients then employ non-uniform Poisson sampling to randomly select a subset of records based on these probabilities, and apply the DP-SGD algorithm (abadi2016deep, ) for local model updates.

The per-record privacy budget accountant. Another important task for completing rPDP-FL is to keep track of the usage of the privacy budget for each of the records in the course of training. Once the privacy budget runs out, individuals can opt out of the remaining training. In our work, we introduce a monitoring module, called the budget accountant, which is in charge of privacy budget accounting: (1) Pre-check at the beginning of the communication round if an individual has sufficient privacy budget to participate in the current round; (2) Compute and update the accumulated privacy cost of an individual after the current communication round is over.

6.3. Discussions

Generalization of the SCF strategy. A distinct characteristic of the SCF strategy lies in its independence from the inherent complexities of specific processes. While this paper primarily focuses on FL applications, the SCF approach serves as a versatile plug-in module applicable to a broad spectrum of tasks that incorporate data sampling and Gaussian mechanism, including private statistical analysis and other SGD-based optimization tasks.

Sampling/Noise trade-offs. In highly privacy-sensitive scenarios, the majority of individuals (e.g., patients) prefer stronger privacy protections, and thus their sensitive personal records are less likely to be included in analysis. We argue that this issue is not about our methodology itself, but an inevitable consequence of the personal privacy decision. One remedy is to adjust the parameters of the Gaussian mechanism, for example, setting a larger noise multiplier Ïƒğœ\sigma such that a higher level of Gaussian noise is used in the computation, resulting in universally increased sampling probabilities qğ‘q with fixed personal privacy budgets. In Figure 6, we illustrate the relationship between optimum DP budgets and their corresponding qğ‘q (represented as a series of dots) across various Ïƒğœ\sigma (represented by different colors). Essentially, there is a trade-off between sampling probability and perturbation noise. However, this approach should be treated with extreme caution, as an improper Ïƒğœ\sigma could lead to a significant degradation in model performance.

7. Experimental Evaluation

In this section, we conduct a thorough empirical analysis to evaluate the performance of both the SCF strategy and the rPDP-FL algorithm. In Subsection 7.1, we focus on evaluating the effectivenss of SCF by comparing it with the other two existing strategies employed for achieving PDP in centralized ML settings. Given the absence of alternative implementations achieving record-level PDP in the context of FL, we assess the utility improvement of rPDP-FL by contrasting it with two conventional methods that do not incorporate personalized privacy preservation in Subsection 7.2.

Privacy Preference Distributions. We simulate different scenarios where users have diverse privacy preferences for their data.

  • â€¢

    ThreeLevels: each record di,jsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{i,j} has the option to select a preferred privacy budget from three distinct choices (categories) {Îµ1,Îµ2,Îµ3}subscriptğœ€1subscriptğœ€2subscriptğœ€3\{\varepsilon_{1},\varepsilon_{2},\varepsilon_{3}\} where Îµ1<Îµ2<Îµ3subscriptğœ€1subscriptğœ€2subscriptğœ€3\varepsilon_{1}<\varepsilon_{2}<\varepsilon_{3}, each denoting strong, moderate, and weak privacy protection, respectively. This simulates practical PDP implementation scenarios where the users can choose from a few predefined privacy categories.

  • â€¢

    BoundedPareto: each record di,jsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{i,j} has an arbitrary Îµi,jâˆˆ[0.1,10]subscriptğœ€ğ‘–ğ‘—0.110\varepsilon_{i,j}\in[0.1,10] that approximately follows a Pareto distribution. This simulates the scenario where a majority of individuals lean towards stringent privacy safeguards, while a smaller subset opts for less restrictive protections in exchange for improved services or other incentives.

  • â€¢

    BoundedMixGauss: each record di,jsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{i,j} has an arbitrary Îµi,jâˆˆ[0.1,10]subscriptğœ€ğ‘–ğ‘—0.110\varepsilon_{i,j}\in[0.1,10] that approximately follows a mixture of three Gaussian distributions. This simulates the scenarios where the privacy choices are multi-modal as in many other complex social systems (WuPNAS18803, ; scalas2005intertrade, ; scalas2004anomalous, ).

Datasets and Models. We consider two classification tasks in the cross-silo FL setting. Additional dataset details are shown in Tab. 1.

  • â€¢

    Fed-Heart-Disease. The first task focuses on predicting the presence of heart disease, utilizing a benchmark healthcare cross-silo FL dataset named Fed-Heart-Disease (terrail2022flamby, ) with a logistic regression model.

  • â€¢

    MNIST-IID and MNIST-NIID. The second is the classic handwritten digit recognition task using the MNIST (lecun2010mnist, ) dataset with a 2-layer CNN model as utilized in (mcmahan2017communication, ). In this case, we follow the IID and non-IID partitioning strategies introduced in (mcmahan2017communication, ) to divide the 60,000 training records into M=10ğ‘€10M=10 subsets. Note that the non-IID strategy generates subsets consisting of records from 5 specific (randomly assigned) classes.

Implementations. All experiments are conducted on a machine with one NVIDIA A40 GPU running on Ubuntu with 256 GB memory. Given that the model training is a randomized process, we repeat all the experiments 5 times and report the mean test accuracy across all clients. Our implementation utilizes the PyTorch Opacus library (opacus, ).

7.1. Comparison of SCF with Existing Strategies

In this section, we show the effectiveness and efficiency of our SCF strategy in terms of model utility and computational cost by comparing it with the following representative approaches in centralized ML settings. Given that both approaches were originally designed in centralized ML settings, the implementation of SCF will be adjusted by simply replacing the employment of Theorem 3 to the existing RDP analysis results (zhu2019deep, ).

  • â€¢

    Filter: also known as RÃ©nyi privacy filter (Algorithm 3 in (feldman2021individual, )), which is an individual privacy accounting method ensuring that the accumulation of squared gradient norms during the training process does not exceed a pre-specified budget and filters out the record once it does.

  • â€¢

    BinarySearch: also known as Individual DP-SGD (IDP-SGD) with the Sample mechanism (Algorithm 1 in (boenisch2023have, )), which is a binary search-based approach aiming for finding the optimal sampling probability within the range of [0,1]01[0,1] for a target privacy budget.

7.1.1. Comparison of SCF with Filter

While both SCF and Filter share a common objective of achieving personalized privacy protection, they significantly differ in the definition of â€œbudgetsâ€: Filter considers a budget for the accumulative squared gradient norms for the records in the training process, while we focus on the DP privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon for the accumulative privacy cost. Achieving a smooth transition between the two quantities is challenging. Therefore, our experiments only considered a simplified personalized privacy scenario ThreeLevels, where the percentage of records with Îµ1subscriptğœ€1\varepsilon_{1}, Îµ2subscriptğœ€2\varepsilon_{2}, and Îµ3subscriptğœ€3\varepsilon_{3} is 70%, 20%, and 10%, respectively. See Table 2 for the detailed parameter configurations. Adhering to the configuration specified in the original paper (feldman2021individual, ), we first incorporate both Filter and SCF into the private batch gradient descent algorithm, and the resulting algorithms are then evaluated on the pooled Fed-Heart-Disease dataset and the MNIST dataset. The results shown in Table 2 demonstrate that SCF outperforms Filter in terms of test accuracy and runtime per update step.

Number of active records. In Figure 7, we plot the number of active records during one run of private GD algorithm with Filter, i.e. those that have not yet exhausted their privacy budget. The results reveal that in scenarios where personalized privacy protection is implemented, particularly when a significant portion of the records adheres to conservative privacy preferences, a considerable number of records undergo early filtration in the training process, which restricts the modelâ€™s capacity to effectively learn from the dataset.

Discussions. We highlight that the absence of explicit guidelines in (feldman2021individual, ) regarding adjusting the hyperparameters of â€œsquared norm budgetâ€ to match a desired privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon poses challenges in ensuring a fair comparison between Filter and SCF in personalized privacy scenarios with diverse continuous privacy preferences among individuals, such as distributions like BoundedMixGauss or BoundedPareto. Besides, SGD involving random subsampling of records no longer offers the expected advantages for enhancing privacy and improving computational efficiency within the individual privacy accounting framework, as claimed in (feldman2021individual, ). Based on the experimental results presented in Table 2 and the limitations discussed above, we exclude the comparison with the Filter approach in the subsequent experiments conducted in the FL settings.

7.1.2. Comparison of SCF with BinarySearch

As we discussed in Section 2, BinarySearch faces a significant limitation in terms of efficiency when dealing with recordsâ€™ privacy budgets that cover values within a continuous range, rather than a discrete subset. To illustrate this, we conduct a toy experiment involving a subset of 6,000 records with privacy budgets following a Pareto distribution ranging from 0.5 to 5.0. The objective is to determine a proper sampling probability for each record. Our experiment results demonstrate that executing the entire searching process via BinarySearch sequentially would take more than 64 minutes on average across 5 trials666This does not account for the time required for model training.. In contrast, SCF achieves both computing the best-fit model and estimating the sampling probability for all records in only around 8 seconds. This represents a substantial improvement in efficiency compared to BinarySearch. Note that we did not evaluate BinarySearch in a parallel manner as this implementation was not discussed in the original paper (boenisch2023have, ) and is not the focus of this paper.

7.2. Utility Improvement through Privacy Personalization

In this section, we evaluate the effectiveness of our rPDP-FL algorithm in providing record-level personalized DP while optimizing for model accuracy. Given the absence of alternative implementations achieving record-level PDP in the FL setting, we established three DP-FedAvg-based baseline methods as follows:

  • â€¢

    Minimum: DP-FedAvg ensuring the most stringent uniform (Îµmâ€‹iâ€‹n,Î´subscriptğœ€ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ›¿\varepsilon_{min},\delta)-DP guarantees, where Îµmâ€‹iâ€‹n=miniâˆˆ[M],jâˆˆ[|Di|]â¡Îµi,jsubscriptğœ€ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€ğ‘—delimited-[]subscriptğ·ğ‘–subscriptğœ€ğ‘–ğ‘—\varepsilon_{min}=\min_{i\in[M],j\in[|D_{i}|]}\varepsilon_{i,j}.

  • â€¢

    Dropout: DP-FedAvg providing moderate uniform (Îµmâ€‹oâ€‹d,Î´subscriptğœ€ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘‘ğ›¿\varepsilon_{mod},\delta)-DP guarantees for a subset of individuals whose privacy budgets Îµi,jsubscriptğœ€ğ‘–ğ‘—\varepsilon_{i,j} are larger than a pre-defined threshold Îµmâ€‹oâ€‹dsubscriptğœ€ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘‘\varepsilon_{mod}. Here, Îµmâ€‹oâ€‹dsubscriptğœ€ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘‘\varepsilon_{mod} is determined as the empirical sample mean of 1|ğ’Ÿ|â€‹âˆ‘i,jÎµi,j1ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœ€ğ‘–ğ‘—\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}|}\sum_{i,j}\varepsilon_{i,j}.

  • â€¢

    PrivacyFree: The vanilla FedAvg (mcmahan2017communication, ) without DP guarantees, which serves as a benchmark for assessing the reduction in joint model utility.

Note that both Minimum and Dropout ensure the accumulative privacy costs of all records remain at/below their specified privacy budget throughout the training process but lead to a significant waste for records with large privacy budgets.

All three types of privacy preference distributions are considered for a comprehensive evaluation of all methodsâ€™ performance. For the ThreeLevels scenario, 70% of records opt for a privacy budget of Îµ1=0.1subscriptğœ€10.1\varepsilon_{1}=0.1, while Îµ2=1.0subscriptğœ€21.0\varepsilon_{2}=1.0 and Îµ3=5.0subscriptğœ€35.0\varepsilon_{3}=5.0 account for 20% and 10%, respectively. Similarly, the BoundedMixGauss distribution is defined as a mixture of ğ’©1â€‹(0.1,0.01)subscriptğ’©10.10.01\mathcal{N}_{1}(0.1,0.01), ğ’©2â€‹(1.0,0.05)subscriptğ’©21.00.05\mathcal{N}_{2}(1.0,0.05) and ğ’©3â€‹(5.0,0.5)subscriptğ’©35.00.5\mathcal{N}_{3}(5.0,0.5) with respective weights of 0.7, 0.2 and 0.1. For the BoundedPareto case, we consider a specific Pareto distribution with shape value of 1.0. These parameters are chosen to simulate the realistic scenarios where majority users have strict privacy requirements. Examples of 1,000 recordsâ€™ privacy preferences are illustrated in the first column of Figure 8.

Hyperparameters. For the Fed-Heart-Disease experiments, we fix the per-client sampling probability Î»ğœ†\lambda=1.0 and Î´ğ›¿\delta=1e-3; for the MNIST experiments, we fix Î»ğœ†\lambda=0.8 and Î´ğ›¿\delta=1e-4. For global and local training procedures, we set the total communication rounds T=15ğ‘‡15T=15 and the local training steps Ï„=50ğœ50\tau=50. We explore a variety of constant learning rates (e.g., [0.1, 0.05, 0.01, 0.005, 0.001]) for the best results.

Utility results. The evaluation results under various privacy preference distributions, as shown in Figure 8, consistently demonstrate the superiority of our rPDP-FL method over both Minimum and Dropout across diverse FL datasets. Specifically, the advantages over the Minimum method suggest that the model benefits from records with larger privacy budgets, while its advantages over the Dropout method imply that even records with conservative privacy budgets contribute positively to the training process. These findings underscore the crucial role of personalized privacy integration in achieving a more favorable trade-off between privacy and utility, particularly in scenarios where most individuals exhibit a strong emphasis on privacy concerns.

Upon comparing the results between MNIST-IID and MNIST-NIID, we observed a consistent reduction in test accuracy in the non-IID case across Minimum, Dropout, and our proposed method. This decline arises from the inherent limitations of the DP-FedAvg algorithm under a heterogeneous environment (noble2022differentially, ). Despite this deterioration, itâ€™s noteworthy that the utility advantages stemming from incorporating privacy personalization remain.

8. Conclusion

In this paper, we studied an unexplored real-world challenge to enable record-level personalized differential privacy in federated learning. Our proposed solution is a novel framework called rPDP-FL, which employs a two-stage hybrid sampling scheme with non-uniform record-level sampling. We devise an efficient strategy, referred to as Simulation-CurveFitting(SCF), to estimate the individual sampling probabilities for all records associated with varying privacy budgets. Our investigation reveals a valuable insight related to rPDP-FL, i.e., the one-to-one correspondence between recordsâ€™ sampling probabilities and their accumulative privacy costs during the entire training process can be modeled by a simple exponential function. Through empirical demonstrations, we show that our solutions yield significant performance enhancements compared to baselines that overlook personalized privacy preservation.

As an early exploration into FL with personalized privacy protection, our work lays a foundation for future in-depth investigations and highlights several promising directions, such as exploring user/device-level PDP in cross-silo/cross-device FL, where each user/device may possess multiple records. This problem can be further explored with detailed considerations, taking into account factors like whether each user contributes data to multiple clients simultaneously or whether an individual user may have diverse privacy preferences for their distinct records.
